channel.title: Action on Jbuttons
channel.description:
How do you make it when you press a button a new frame opens? I tried the bit in frell's tutorial but it didn't work.
Thanks, x19

item.title: Action on Jbuttons
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:12, topic:186518”][quote author=Frell link=topic=248982.msg2094084#msg2094084 date=1204945988]

How do you make it when you press a button a new frame opens? I tried the bit in frell’s tutorial but it didn’t work.

Thanks, x19

never added that. But you just add all the components inside the action method.

EDIT: just spent about an hour of my life updating my tutorial, it should be more helpful now, and added JFrame adding.
[/quote]Don’t listen to Frell! His tutorial(s) degenerate your general knowledge.

It may be a bit sloppy, but it all works. I even updated it earlier today to make some confusing parts more understandable. Half the time i go back and look at it and laugh and wonder why i didn’t explain that.

And most of the time, when you look at professional code, they have extra things added in there that may throw him off.

If a person requires a noob-tutorial, they shouldn’t be doing the thing the tutorial teaches.[/quote]
True, but if there making something as simple as a server helper or something, they dont usually care about the other stuff.

Read full topic

item.title: Action on Jbuttons
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.event.ActionListener;
import java.awt.event.ActionEvent;

public class ButtonTest extends JFrame {

	public ButtonTest() {
		super("ButtonTest");
		this.setSize(300, 300);
		this.setDefaultCloseOperation(WindowConstants.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
		JButton button1 = new JButton("Open Frame");
		JButton button2 = new JButton("Open Dialog");
		button1.addActionListener(this);
		button2.addActionListener(this);
		this.add(button1);
		this.add(button2);
	}

	public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
		if (e.getActionCommand().endsWith("Frame")) {
			JFrame frame = new JFrame("New Frame");
			frame.setSize(300, 300);
			frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(WindowConstants.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
			frame.setVisible(true);
		} else if (e.getActionCommand().endsWith("Dialog")) {
			JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(this, "A test message dialog");
		}
	}

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		new ButtonTest().setVisible(true);
	}
}

There. Go see the Java documents to view more information on JFrames and JOptionPane dialogs.

Read full topic

item.title: Action on Jbuttons
item.dc:creator: @super_OLDACCOUNT super_OLDACCOUNT
item.description:
@super_OLDACCOUNT wrote:

myJButton.addActionListener(new MyActionListenerImpl());

[code]import java.awt.event.ActionListener;
import java.awt.event.ActionEvent;
import java.awt.Frame;

public class MyActionListenerImpl implements ActionListener {

public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent actionEvent) {
    openNewFrame();
}

private void openNewFrame() {
    Frame frame = new Frame();
    customizeFrame(frame);
    frame.setVisible(true);
}

private void customizeFrame(Frame frame) {
    // ...
}

}[/code]

Read full topic
